did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Papers of George C. Baker 1903-1958 (bulk 1943-1957)
did.abstract: Correspondence, research materials, published and unpublished manuscripts and articles, slides, photographs, and one audio tape, primarily from 1943 to 1957, of anthropologist George C. Barker. The collection documents Barker's anthropological research into folk drama and ritual, the social functions of language, the Pachuco language of Hispanic youths, and Yaqui Indian culture and customs. A 1964 gift to the Southwest Folklore Archives from George C. Barker, Sr. Deaccessioned from the collection in 1993 were approximately 0.2 feet of duplicates and items of a personal nature. In 1996 two 11 x 14 black-and-white photographs by Alfred A. Cohn were transferred to the L. Marguerite Collier Collection, Southwest Folklore Center Manuscripts Collection SWF 005.

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

did.langmaterial: Materials are in English and Spanish.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Restricted. Researchers are restricted to an edited user cassette copy of Barker’s recorded interview of Pachuco language speakers.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Papers of George C. Baker, 1903-1958 (SWF 004). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Processed by Lisa Janzer, Pat Kittelson, 1993; Ila Abernathy, Jenny Loengard, 1996; Scott B. Denlinger, 1997.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: George C. Barker was born on November 15, 1912, in Omaha, Nebraska. He received his A.B. in history from the University of California, Los Angeles, in 1935 and an M.S. in journalism from Columbia University in 1936. After developing an interest in anthropology, he attended the University of Chicago and received an M.A. (1943) and a Ph.D. (1947) in that field. He was elected a Fellow of the American Anthropological Association in 1947.

Despite recurring poor health and physical handicaps, Barker engaged in a number of research activities. His primary areas of interest were folk drama, folk religion, Native American cultures in the Southwest, the social functions of language, and the Pachuco language of Mexican-American youths. He published various works on these topics.

Barker served as a Research Associate at the Institute of Human Relations, Yale University, in 1942, and at the University of Arizona in 1947-48. In 1950 he became a Research Associate in Anthropology at the University of California, Los Angeles, a position he held until his death in 1958. While in Los Angeles, he worked with the Los Angeles County Probation Department and the Neighborhood Youth Association of West Los Angeles on problems of Mexican-American youth.

For additional biographical information, see Harry T. Getty's biographical introduction in the 1958 reissue of: Barker, George C. Pachuco: An American-Spanish Argot and its Social Functions in Tucson, Arizona. University of Arizona Bulletin XXI:1. Social Science Bulletin, no. 18. (Tucson: University of Arizona Press, 1958) [reprinted 1970].

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into six series.

list.item: Series III: Published and Unpublished Articles, Papers and Reviews, 1936-1958
Series IV: Field and Research Notes, 1940-1958
Series VI: Visual and Audio Materials, 1940s-1950s

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of George C. Barker’s research notes, correspondence and field notes from his research activities. The research notes consist primarily of articles, offprints, newspaper clippings and secondary literature accumulated by Barker during the course of his study and research in bilingualism and folklore. Many items address issues of bilingualism in the southwestern United States, and its social manifestations.

Barker’s correspondence documents exchanges between him and his colleagues in anthropology and folklore, including Edward P. Dozier and Edward H. Spicer. Also included are correspondence with Frances Gillmor, several letters to and from the Reverend Anthony Soto, one family letter, and personal correspondence with Mexican American families in Tucson. The collection includes some correspondence addressed to Barker’s father, George C. Barker, Sr.

Barker’s works include his publications, and drafts of published and unpublished articles, papers, monographs, and reviews, field and research notes from his doctoral thesis and other projects, and transcripts of interviews. There is a handwritten manuscript of Coloquio de pastores del hijo pródigo, transcribed by ensayador Aristéo Flores, from Chapalá, Mexico. This was edited and translated by Barker and published in Folklore Studies: 2 by the University of California Press in 1953.

Visual and audio materials include 379 original kodachrome slides and 151 copies, about 70 of which are of Yaqui village scenes and Holy Week processions in the Yaqui village at Hermosillo, Mexico. The other slides are of travel scenes in various countries, inconclusively referenced in notes for a presentation and an undated index, both stored with the slides. Photographs and negatives include photos of Yaqui Indian ceremonies, several postcards, and unidentified photos of Mexico, Spain, and various ceremonies. The collection includes reel tapes of Pachuco dialogue, songs, and interviews. An edited reel has been made from the original paper tape reel. Personal names have been edited out of this duplicate reel.

Preservation xerostatic copies of a substantial portion of the materials have been made. Boxes 1-5 of the collection contain working copies of the materials, a small number of uncopied originals, and slides and photographs. Original documents of which working copies have been made are stored in boxes 6-9. The working copies of the audio tapes are housed in the Southwest Folklore Center Manuscript Collection SWF 009, with the call numbers 85.2/C.1 and 85.2/R.1.
Researchers must obtain permission from the coordinator of the University of Arizona Southwest Folklore Center or the University of Arizona manuscripts librarian to use the original documents.

did.unittitle: Research Materials,

scopecontent.p: Books, pamphlets, articles and papers collected by Barker on a variety of sociological, anthropological and folk topics related to Barker's research. There are also newspaper and magazine clippings, programs, minutes, and papers from various activities. Material is arranged by type of material, and thereunder chronologically when possible.

did.unittitle: Published works, pamphlets, articles, and brochures,

Notes and two papers from a conference, "Work Conference on Research Problems of Bilingualism 1954"; and a paper by Leonard Broom and Eshref Shevky, "Mexicans in the United States: A Problem in Social Differentiation",
Announcements, fliers, programs, street maps, meeting minutes, and miscellaneous materials,
Newspaper and magazine clippings,
Correspondence,

scopecontent.p: Correspondence between Barker and his colleagues in anthropology and folklore, and with persons regarding sources of information for research. Also included are a family letter and personal letters from Mexican American contacts in Tucson, Arizona and California. Items are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to his grandmother,
did.abstract: Describes a camping trip taken with his father in the previous week.

did.unittitle: Letter from Thomas Sebeok to Barker,
did.abstract: Answers questions Barker posed to him concerning Sebeok’s bilingualism.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ralph Beals, Univ. of California, to Barker,
did.abstract: Responds to Barker’s query regarding areas in which would be appropriate for him to do his dissertation field work on bilingualism.

did.unittitle: Letter from Harry T. Getty, Univ. of Arizona, to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses possible communities in which Barker could do his dissertation work. Discusses Tucson’s suitability.

did.unittitle: Letter from Abe Halpern, Univ. of Chicago, to Barker,
did.abstract: Transmits materials on language use habits in Guatemala.

did.unittitle: Letter from Frank E. Moore to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses Redlands, California as a possible location for Barker’s dissertation research.

did.unittitle: Letter from Harry T. Getty, Univ. of Arizona, to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses language use in the Tucson, Arizona Mexican and Mexican American community.

did.unittitle: Letter from Joe Chalita Hernandez to Barker,
did.abstract: Conveys personal news (partly in Spanish).

did.unittitle: Letter from Mrs. Joe Hernandez to Barker,
did.abstract: Personal news of the family and envelope.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Manuel Cajero,
did.abstract: Asks that Cajero fill out and return a language use survey.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ricardo Manzo,
did.abstract: Describes the preliminary findings of his language use research.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Rebecca Mariscal, Alianza Hispano-Americana,
did.abstract: Asks that Mariscal complete a questionnaire on language use in her family. Attached is a preliminary summary of his research [for Tucson area speakers?].

did.unittitle: Letter from Maria Huerta to Barker,
did.abstract: Conveys family news.

did.unittitle: Letter from Maria [Huerta] to Barker,
did.abstract: Family news.

did.unittitle: Letter from Maria Huerta to Barker,
did.abstract: Family news.

did.unittitle: Letter from L.E. Romero and Gila to Barker,
did.abstract: Personal greeting accompanying a Christmas card.

did.unittitle: Letter from Mr. and Mrs. J. Hernandez to Mr. and Mrs. George Barker [Sr.],
did.abstract: Conveys greetings and personal news.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Leland Sonnichsen,
did.abstract: Barker shows Interest in El Paso Pachuco and requests verification of his own information of the origin of the argot.

did.unittitle: Letter from Leland Sonnichsen to Barker,
did.abstract: Has turned over Barker's letter to Gabriel Cordova, a graduate student and former court interpreter who compiled a list of several thousand words of the argot.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Leland Sonnichsen,
did.abstract: Conveys his thanks for the information.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Gabriel Cordova,
did.abstract: Contains acknowledgment of the information given on origin of Pachuco. Gives Barker's professional background and explains his interest in Tucson Pachuco.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer] to Barker,
did.abstract: Mentions his slow progress on “People of Pascua” and discusses issues and approaches to the "off-reservation research program" on Arizona Indians that he intends to do in conjunction with Barker.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Mr. Donald Biery,
did.abstract: Asks the Superintendent of the Sherman Institute the questions that Spicer raised in his letter (cf. above letter).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer],
did.abstract: Reply to Spicer’s letter of July 27, 1948 (item 22, above).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer],
did.abstract: Reports on a visit to Sherman Institute where he did some preliminary data collecting for a study of off-reservation Arizona Indians. (cf. folder 1, item 23).

did.unittitle: Letter from Maria to Olive [Barker],
did.abstract: Contains a description of the feast of the Virgin of Guadalupe at Morelia.

did.unittitle: Letter from Aristéo Flores to Barker,
did.abstract: Thanks Barker for making him aware of another copy of El hijo pródigo.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer] to Barker,
did.abstract: Reply to Barker’s letter of August 14, 1948 (item 25, above). Also contains a report on his two new books People of Pascua and Potam, a Yaqui Village in Sonora.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Frances Gillmor,
did.abstract: Describes how he acquired the religious folk drama El hijo pródigo in 1948 and points out the unusual nature of the text which "combines the story of the prodigal son with that of the pilgrimage of the shepherds to Bethlehem."

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Frances Gillmor,
did.abstract: Thanks Gillmor for bibliographical advice and mentions her research on "dance dramas with a ‘fighting pattern.’”

did.unittitle: Letter from Arthur L. Campa to Barker,
did.abstract: Gives his opinion on the Los pastores play collected by Barker and calls Barker's attention to the two cycles of plays he published in the University of New Mexico Bulletin.

did.unittitle: Letter from Frances Gillmor to Barker,
did.abstract: Gives bibliographical information for the Los pastores play and discusses publication possibilities. Also mentions Barker's Pachuco bulletin.

did.unittitle: Letter from Frances Gillmor to Barker,
did.abstract: Mentions the Pachuco bulletin and publication possibilities for Barker's folk play. Also describes progress on folk plays with "fighting patterns."

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Dick [family name not given],
did.abstract: Excerpt of a conversation that Barker had with an informant in West Los Angeles (in Spanish).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Charles F. Harding III,
did.abstract: Outlines his intended research on "language usage and acculturation among Mexican Americans in Southern California.”

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Mr. Robert E.G. Harris,
did.abstract: Requests information on "wetbacks" for the "occupational survey of persons of Mexican descent in southern California."

did.unittitle: Letter from Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier?] to Barker,
did.abstract: Largest part of the letter concerns the annual performance of a morality play witnessed at Christmas time in San Antonio, Texas. Attached are “Notes on the presentation of Los pastores.”

did.unittitle: Letter from Aristéo Flores to George and Olive Barker,
did.abstract: Conveys personal news and asks the Barkers if they can offer him employment.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Aristéo Flores,
did.abstract: Responds to the above letter. Offers an address where Flores can inquire about work opportunities.

did.unittitle: Letter from Aristéo Flores to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses the possibility of filming a version of El hijo pródigo. Asks if the Barkers have any contacts in the film industry. Asks if the Barkers can assist him in obtaining U.S. citizenship.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Aristéo Flores,
did.abstract: Responds to the above letter. Explains that he cannot offer help in obtaining U.S. citizenship.

did.unittitle: Letter from Lyle Saunders to Barker,
did.abstract: Thanks Barker for a reprint of "Growing up in a Bilingual Community." He thinks that a recognition of language and cultural differences will help provide adequate medical care to the Spanish-speaking people of Denver.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Mr. Afton D. Nance,
did.abstract: Inquires whether the State Department of Education, California, would be interested in an outline for a home study course in citizenship for Mexican immigrants.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to George Mann,
did.abstract: Referred to Mann by Afton Nance. Barker inquires again what programs there for adult Mexican immigrants In English and citizenship. Suggests the possibility of a home study course.

did.unittitle: Letter from George Mann to Barker,
did.abstract: Expresses interest in the home study course in English and citizenship for adult Mexican immigrants that Barker suggested.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to George Mann,
did.abstract: Short note that he Is assembling material for the home study course.

did.unittitle: Letter from David L. Olmstead to Barker,
did.abstract: Responds to a Barker letter [?] dealing with acculturation and language.

did.unittitle: Letter from Robert Redfield to Barker,
did.abstract: Cautions Barker to study bilingualism without applying it to social mobility, delinquency, and jobs based on the data he is going to elicit.

did.unittitle: Letter from Waldemar A. Nielsen to Barker,
did.abstract: Rejection of Barker’s proposal to the Ford Foundation for a bilingual study.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ed [Dozier],
did.abstract: Contains comments on the manuscript about the Tewa on First Mesa of the Hopi Reservation.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to David Olmstead,
did.abstract: Response to Olmstead’s letter of March 25, 1953. Deals with their different opinions on language and acculturation; Barker holds that bilingualism is possible without acculturation while Olmstead has taken the opposite view.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to R.R. [i.e. Robert Redfield],
did.abstract: Reply to Redfield’s letter of April 13, 1953 (folder 3, item 4). It is a thank you note and indicates that Barker intends to revise his proposal for the study of bilingualism rejected by the Ford Foundation.

did.unittitle: Letter from Stanley H. Robe to Barker,
did.abstract: Gives a short summary of Juan Rael’s talk on pastores plays at the meeting of the California folklore society. Attached is a sheet that shows the distribution of pastores plays and different types.

did.unittitle: Letter from Matt [i.e. T.M. Pearce] to Barker,
did.abstract: Thanks Barker for sending him Rael’s map on Los pastores plays (cf. above letter) and discusses the conclusions Rael presented at the meeting.

did.unittitle: Letter from Kurt H. Wolf, Institut für Sozialforschung an der Johann-Wolfgang-Goethe-Universität, Frankfurt a. Main, Germany, to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses his experiences of bilingualism in Germany, especially between High German and German dialect.

did.unittitle: Letter from Dave [i.e. David Weingarden] to Barker,
did.abstract: List of the angel’s names for the study Barker is doing for the Neighborhood Settlement Association.

did.unittitle: Postcard from Porfirio Gonzalez to Barker [George C. Barker, Sr.?],
did.abstract: Discusses payment received for work performed for Barker.

did.unittitle: Letter from Einar Haugen, University of Wisconsin, to Barker,
did.abstract: Inquires about the nature of Barker’s bibliography on bilingualism, and plans for its publication, if any.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Kurt [i.e., Kurt H. Wolf],
did.abstract: Responds to Wolf’s letter of July 15, 1953 (folder 3, item 11). Discusses varieties of English in the U.S.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Joseph B. Casagrande, Stanford,
did.abstract: Reports on his exchange of letters with Wolf and suggests an inter-university seminar on bilingualism.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Prof. Einar Haugen, University of Wisconsin,
did.abstract: Describes the nature of his bibliography on bilingualism, and points out that it will address the “social functions of bilingualism.”

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to George M. Foster,
did.abstract: Acknowledges support given in regard to Barker's pastores play and promises a copy of the recently published play.

did.unittitle: Letter from Albert R. Marquez to Barker,
did.abstract: Attached is: "Descendants of First Settlers Witness Dedication of old Rancho Marker," Palisadian XXVI:21 (September 18, 1953), in Spanish.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Aurelio M. Espinosa,
did.abstract: Acknowledges information given on The Shepherds' Play of the Prodigal Son and promises a copy of the play.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to T. M. Pearce,
did.abstract: Acknowledges receipt of the copy of The New Mexican Shepherds' Play and mentions the recent publication of Barker's own pastores play.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Professor Arthur L. Campa,
did.abstract: Announces the shipment of an autographed copy of Barker's pastores play and acknowledges Prof. Campa’s "pioneer work in the field of religious folk drama in the Southwest."

did.unittitle: Letter from Peg [i.e. Margaret Mudgett] to Barker,
did.abstract: Acknowledges the excellent work Barker did for the Neighborhood Settlement Association.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Prof. J. Philipson, U. of San Paulo,
did.abstract: Thanks Philipson for sending him an offprint.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Mr. Albert A. Marquez,
did.abstract: Invites Marquez to attend a playing of his recorded dedication speech of the Marquez Rancho Marker.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to T.M. Pearce,
did.abstract: Comments on a paper by Pearce on Los pastores plays and suggests that there might have been a cycle of these plays rather than a master play of which all "episodes" are a part.

did.unittitle: Letter from Aurelio M. Espinosa to Barker,
did.abstract: Acknowledges the receipt of a Los pastores manuscript.

did.unittitle: Letter from George M. Foster to Barker,
did.abstract: Acknowledges the receipt of Barker's published Los pastores play.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Everett C. Hughes,
did.abstract: Accompanies a manuscript submitted to the American Journal of Sociology.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Louis J. King,
did.abstract: Requests that King and Barker compare notes on the "Angels", the follow up study Barker was doing for the Neighborhood Settlement Association.

did.unittitle: Letter from Juan B. Real to Barker,
did.abstract: Acknowledges the complimentary copy of Barker's Los pastores and mentions that Real did not find pastores plays south of Mexico.

did.unittitle: Letter from A.W. Woolsey to Barker,
did.abstract: Inquires about Barker's The Shepherds' Play of the Prodigal Son and mentions that the Texas State College for Women has two pastores plays.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Editor, Fortnight,
did.abstract: Congratulates the editor on the unbiased article on teenage gangs in Los Angeles and briefly states his own involvement with the Neighborhood Settlement Association.

did.unittitle: Letter from John B. Carroll, American Council of Learned Studies (ACLS), to Barker,
did.abstract: Expresses approval of Barker’s research proposal for an interdisciplinary study of Mexican bilingualism in Los Angeles, and informs him that the ACLS Committee on the Language Program will help procure funds.

did.unittitle: Letter from Einar Haugen, Univ. of Wisc., to Prof. John B. Carroll,
did.abstract: Supports and endorses Barker’s proposal to Carroll for the study.

did.unittitle: Letter from John B. Carroll, ACLS, to Barker,
did.abstract: Reports on the comments received from Einar Haugen and Mary Haas.

did.unittitle: Letter from John B. Carroll, ACLS, to Barker,
did.abstract: Informs Barker that he may delay the submission of his revised proposal.

did.unittitle: Postcard from Pacific Palisades Art Association to Mr. and Mrs. Barker, [Sr.?],
did.abstract: Announcement of a lecture to be given by Barker followed by a lecture on Spanish art given by George, Sr.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to John B. Carroll, ACLS,
did.abstract: Informs Carroll he will send the revised proposal by the end of the month.

did.unittitle: Letter from John B. Carroll, ACLS, to Barker,
did.abstract: Carroll received the proposal, and gives Barker the addresses of other members of the Committee on the Language Program.

did.unittitle: Letter from Jose Perez Vidal to Barker,
did.abstract: Transmits Cantos populares españoles, Seville, 1882, and envelope (in Spanish).

did.unittitle: Letter from Albert H. Marckwardt to Barker,
did.abstract: Asks for a copy of Barker’s research proposal submitted to the ACLS.

did.unittitle: Letter from Leslie E. Eichelberger to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses Barker's Neighborhood Association work.

did.unittitle: Letter from Joseph B. Casagrande to Barker,
did.abstract: Accompanies report on a “work conference on bilingualism” and two papers.

did.unittitle: Letter from Sister Celine, S.S.S., to Barker,
did.abstract: Promises support for Barker's "cultural influence'' study of a Catholic Youth Organization club in Los Angeles, Calif.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier],
did.abstract: Comments on the Southwestern Project In Comparative Psycholinguistics and on his own bilingual study entitled at that point, "A Study of Communication Patterns and Social Isolation among Mexican American Boys' Gangs in Los Angeles.”

did.unittitle: Letter from Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier] to Barker,
did.abstract: Contains information on goals and working techniques of the Southwestern Project in Comparative Psycholinguistics.

did.unittitle: Letter from William Whitley to Barker,
did.abstract: Acknowledges interest Barker was taking in a special series of CBS Television Pacific Network.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Mr. A.F. Schaeffer,
did.abstract: Concerns U.S. Public Health Service research grant application administrative matters.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Harold R. Muntz,
did.abstract: Transmits the results of his language study to the Los Angeles County Probation Department.

did.unittitle: Postcard from Bill Gutierrez to Barker,
did.abstract: Asks for a copy of the boys' gang study in Los Angeles.

did.unittitle: Letter from Mrs. W.L. Clemens to Barker,
did.abstract: Thanks Barker for participating in a panel [at Puente High School?].

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Dr. Corbato,
did.abstract: Transmits paper on penitential processions in Spain. Corbato returns the letter with annotations.

did.unittitle: Letter from Edmund O. Barker to Barker,
did.abstract: Contains bibliographical material on the Mexican shepherds' play and mentions the "‘boycott trials’ of the Negroes in Montgomery.”

did.unittitle: Letter from Father Radtke [et al.] to "Dear Parishioner,",
did.abstract: Announces the Easter ceremonies of the Sacred Heart Church in Nogales, Ariz.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier],
did.abstract: Announces a field trip to New Mexico to observe the San Buenaventura celebrations at Cochiti for his study of "Catholic ritual processions in Spain and the American Southwest" and also expresses the hope to be able to talk to members of the psycholinguistic project.

did.unittitle: Anonymous postcard to Barker,
did.abstract: Postcard consists of a hand-drawn map.

did.unittitle: Letter from Frances Gillmor to Barker,
did.abstract: Thanks Barker for participating in a panel on folk drama at the folklore meeting.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Mr. Herrera,
did.abstract: Asks the Governor of Cochiti Pueblo questions about the corn dance and procession of the feast day of San Buenaventura.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier],
did.abstract: Comments on "Ed's" [i.e. Dozier’s?] paper on evaluating "aboriginal rituals from the standpoints of degree of sacredness, extend of community participation, and extent of public visibility and outside participation."

did.unittitle: Letter from Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier] to Barker,
did.abstract: Contains further information about Pueblo Catholicism and Indian ceremonies in reply to Barker's letter (cf. above letter).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Edward P. Dozier,
did.abstract: Acknowledges help given by Dozier at the meeting in Santa Monica and refers to their papers on Pueblo materials.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier] to Barker,
did.abstract: Talks about the possibility of publishing the three papers on Pueblo and Yaqui materials together (Edward Spicer, Edward Dozier, and Barker).

did.unittitle: Letter from Frances Gillmor to Barker,
did.abstract: Thanks Barker for the wonderful Santa Monica meetings.

did.unittitle: Letter from Wayland D. Hand to Barker,
did.abstract: Friendly note.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer],
did.abstract: Discusses the joint publishing venture for the three papers again.

did.unittitle: Letter from Thomas A. Sebeok to Barker,
did.abstract: Friendly note referring to recent meetings.

did.unittitle: Letter from Edward H. Spicer to Barker,
did.abstract: Agrees to the joint publishing of the three papers on Pueblo and Yaqui materials. Agrees to do the overall comments.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer],
did.abstract: Comments on the three papers in regard to Linton's Acculturation in Seven American Indian Tribes.

did.unittitle: Letter from Ed [i.e. Edward Dozier] to Barker,
did.abstract: Comments on his [Dozier’s] intended revisions to his paper planned for publication with Barker’s and Spicer’s.

did.unittitle: Letter from Sheilagh Brooks and Richard H. Brooks to Barker,
did.abstract: Mentions their fieldwork in northwestern Mexico and also refers to a Los pastores manuscript they have collected.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Ned [i.e. Edward Spicer],
did.abstract: Refers again to the joint publishing venture and comments on Spicer's paper.

did.unittitle: Letter from Wayland D. Hand to Barker,
did.abstract: Discusses the use of photographs in Barker's article in Western Folklore (October issue). Article is on Yaqui Easter ceremonies.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Wayland D. Hand,
did.abstract: Promises a selection of photographs and the manuscript by the end of the month (cf. above letter).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Esther Goldfrank,
did.abstract: Requests information about a manuscript of Mexican dance drama originally collected by Elsie Clews Parsons. Barker had received the manuscript from Ralph Beals.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Sheilagh and Richard Brooks,
did.abstract: Contains suggestions for questions to ask their Informant (cf. the Brooks’s letter of April 27, 1957) in regard to their Los pastores play. Also mentions Elsie Clews Parson’s Mexican dance drama of the Mexican Revolution (cf. previous letter).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Muriel Thayer Painter,
did.abstract: Sends his manuscript of his paper on the Yaqui Easter ceremonies in Hermosillo, Mexico, and asks her comments. The letter also contains additional information on the Yaqui Easter ceremony.

did.unittitle: Letter from Wayland [i.e. Wayland D. Hand] to Barker,
did.abstract: Friendly note.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Eugenio Cabrero,
did.abstract: Mentions a field trip to Spain to do research on the Spanish background of Southwestern religious folk dramas. Seeks support of the Del Amo Foundation.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Russell H. Fitzgibbon,
did.abstract: Concerns the financial support of his research on the Spanish background of Mexican folk dramas in the Southwest by the Del Amo Foundation (cf. previous letter).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Sheilagh and Richard H. Brooks,
did.abstract: Mentions the Brooks’s Los pastores play and some interesting parallels to other folk dramas of the time. Gives no specifics parallels, however.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Russell H. Fitzgibbon,
did.abstract: Outlines his research project in Spain for the Committee of Latin American Studies. Intends to study the Spanish background of the Southwestern folk dramas (cf. Barker’s letters of June 20 and July 29, 1957).

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Russell H. Fitzgibbon,
did.abstract: Asks for an acknowledgment of the materials sent (cf. Barker’s letters of June 20 and July 29, 1957).

did.unittitle: Letter from Eugenio Cabrero to Barker,
did.abstract: Del Amo Foundation declines to fund research in Spain.

did.unittitle: Letter from Richard and Sheilagh Brooks to Barker,
did.abstract: Promises further talk with informant on the Los pastores manuscript.

did.unittitle: Letter from the Rev. Anthony Soto to Barker,
did.abstract: Contains historical background of Pala Mission and gives also some general information of the Corpus Christi processions at the mission.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to the Rev. Anthony Soto,
did.abstract: Acknowledges information and inquires about mission records, the changes in the Corpus Christi procession and changes in administration.

did.unittitle: Letter from the Rev. Anthony Soto to Barker,
did.abstract: Provides the name of missionaries who worked at Pala.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to the Rev. Anthony Soto,
did.abstract: Thanks Soto for his help and asks for information on other processions at San Luis Rey and Pala. Barker intends to make a study of the Pala Corpus Christi procession similar to the one he did on Yaqui Easter ceremonies at Hermosillo, Mexico.

did.unittitle: Letter from Richard H. Brooks to Barker,
did.abstract: Asks Barker's advice on the publication of their Los pastoresplay.

did.unittitle: Letter from the Rev. Anthony Soto to Barker,
did.abstract: Supplies additional information on processions at Pala and San Luis Rey and also gives a few sources.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to Richard H. Brooks,
did.abstract: Promises to collaborate on the article to be published with the translation of the Brooks’ Los pastores play.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to the Rev. Anthony Soto,
did.abstract: Acknowledges the information provided by Soto and asks for a brochure written by an Indian on early Indian life at San Luis Rey.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to the Rev. Anthony Soto,
did.abstract: Mentions the receipt of Indian Life at Mission San Luis Rey and announces a visit to Pala during Holy Week.

did.unittitle: Letter from Barker to the Gift Shop, Old Mission San Luis Rey, California,
did.abstract: Payment for Indian Life at Mission San Luis Rey, sent by the Rev. Anthony Soto.

did.unittitle: Letter from the Rev. Anthony Soto to Barker,
did.abstract: Arranges a time for a visit with Barker during his intended visit (Holy Week).

did.unittitle: Postcard from Jean K. Adams (Pauma Valley Motor Lodge) to Barker,
did.abstract: Confirms his reservation for Holy Week.

did.unittitle: Letter from Richard H. Brooks to Barker,
did.abstract: Confirms arrangement for collaboration on the Los pastores article.

did.unittitle: Letter from George Barker (Sr.) to Richard H. Brooks,
did.abstract: Announces his son's death and returns the Los pastores manuscript.

did.unittitle: Published and Unpublished Articles, Papers and Reviews,

scopecontent.p: Text, illustrations, and captions of Barker's works. Printed publications appear first, followed by manuscript copies of informal essays and vignettes and then manuscripts of Barker's anthropological work, in loose chronological order. The Folk Drama subseries contains a handwritten transcript of a Christmas "shepherd's play" provided by Aristéo Flores of Chapalá, Mexico, and Barker's published bilingual edition of the text. Items are arranged by genre and thereunder roughly chronologically.

did.unittitle: Publications (excluding The Shepherds' Play of the Prodigal Son. See box 2, folder 26),
Pilgrimage to Mexico [unpublished manuscript, typescript xerostatic copy],
"The Velorio;" illustrations intended to accompany Pilgrimage to Mexico,

Essays, stories, vignettes: "Back-Country Notes" (1939), Hello Stranger, "Artist for the Million," "The Itinerant Buckeye Painter as Folk Artist: A Profile," and "Backwoods Rembrandt," all unpublished; and "Birthday Party for the Virgin" (New Mexico Folklore Record, 1950).,
"Vanishing Indian Cultures of Southern California" (Pacific Horizons, 1939). Typescript and copy of publication,

Papers, reviews, reports, 1943-1955, on language and linguistics: includes bibliography of sources relating to "Social Functions of Bilingualism"; "Investigating Human Behavior: First Notes for a Primer on General Semantics" (Los Angeles Society for General Semantics, 1939); "The Social Functions of Language" (Etc.: A Review of General Semantics, 1945); a review of Victor Grove's The Language Bar (Etc. A Review of General Semantics, 1952); and other papers and reviews.,
"Growing Up in a Bilingual Community" (Kiva, 1951),
Supplemental materials, prepared by Barker, for a "Ways of Justice" discussion program on international law,
"Notes on Some Conversations with Men of Mexican Descent in an Occupational Group",
Papers on Yaqui and Pueblo adaptations of Spanish Catholic traditions, processions, and ceremony,
“The Shepherds' Play of the Prodigal Son.” Folklore Studies 2 (1953). Publication,
Coloquio de pastores del hijo pródigo from Chapalá, Mexico. Handwritten transcription of folk drama, and related correspondence,
The Prodigal Son suggested treatment, unpublished,
Field and Research Notes,

scopecontent.p: Papers, minutes, field notes, M.A. and Ph.D. notes, and secondary research materials. Items are arranged by subject and thereunder chronologically.

did.unittitle: Field notes and secondary research,
Field notes for M.A. thesis: "Functions of the Ancestral Language among American Immigrants and Their Descendants",
Field notes and secondary research, 1944-1947, primarily relating to field work in Tucson for his doctoral thesis: "Social Functions of Language in a Mexican-American Community",
Notes, Spanish and Mexican folk drama,
Field notes, including notes for Pilgrimage to Mexico,
Vocabulary notes, Pachuco border language,
Interviews and notes, for "Notes on Some Conversations with Men of Mexican Descent in an Occupational Group.",
Field and research notes, interviews, and follow-up studies, primarily for West Los Angeles Neighborhood Settlement Association work with gangs,
Field and secondary-research notes, on Catholic ritual processions and ceremonies, Yaqui Indian Holy Week ceremonies, and New Mexican Pueblo Indian ceremonies,
Field notes, Pala Indians; miscellaneous,
Proposals, including proposals and other materials on semantics, bilingualism, school survey in Tucson, Pachuco language, and work with gangs in Los Angeles,
Miscellaneous additions, working copies,

Miscellaneous materials, including foundation lists, bibliographies, research and field notes and notebooks covering the entire scope of Barker's professional career, and material about his Pachuco language study and informants,
Poems and Essays,

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous poetry and notes, and handwritten and typed copies of the essay "When I was a Child."

did.unittitle: Published ephemera (clippings), primarily poetry,
Essays and poems,
When I Was a Child typescript,
When I Was a Child, holograph manuscript, and miscellaneous writing,
Visual and Audio Materials,

scopecontent.p: There are 379 original color slides and 151 duplicates. Approximately 70 each of slides and duplicates are of Yaqui village scenes and Holy Week processions at Hermosillo, Sonora, Mexico. The rest are travel slides of various countries, largely unidentified. The slides are arranged as follows: unlabeled originals in metal mounts (220); cardboard-mounted duplicates (151), all marked "AV Services, U of A" (duplicates of the first 50 metal-mounted originals plus 1 unidentified slide from the same series, and of 100 of the cardboard-mounted originals); 159 originals in cardboard mounts.

Photographic materials consist of 8” x 10” black and white enlargements of Yaqui Indian ceremonies; 12 black and white postcards of Easter ceremonies at Pascua village, Tucson, Arizona; of Yaqui leader Louis Hernandez; and of a cathedral in Guadalajara, Mexico; and several unidentified photos of various people and locations. There are 11 4” x 5” negatives of photos corresponding to the 8” x 10” enlargements of Yaqui ceremonies, one set marked “Hermosillo.”

Audio materials consist of interviews and examples of the Pachuco language used by Tucson area gangs in the 1940s. The recordings were initially made on two 7” tape reels, one with a paper substrate. These original tapes were duplicated onto a 10" tape reel with background noise removed and an edited 7" working copy. These tape reels have themselves been copied onto working cassettes, and housed in the Southwest Folklore Center cassette tape collection, SWF 009, with the call numbers 85.2/C.1 and 85.2/R.1. Due to the sensitive and personal nature of the material Barker recorded, names of persons and other identifying information have been deleted from the working copy. The duplicate reels and the fragile, paper tape original are stored with the other original materials in the collection. (Note: the tapes open with classical piano music, followed by informal interactions and then the Pachuco interviews.)
Items are arranged by type of material.

did.unittitle: Suggested 20-minute presentation of the visual materials for “The Yaqui Easter Ceremony at Hermosillo;” undated rough index of slides (does not correspond to accessioned order or total number of originals, but contains identifying commentary),
Slides, originals, in metal mounts,
Slides, copies; followed by original slides in cardboard mounts,
Photographs and postcards,
Negatives,
did.abstract: The following boxes contain the original documents copied to make up the working collection described above. Material in the following boxes may only be used with the permission of the coordinator of the Southwest Folklore Center or the University of Arizona manuscripts librarian. The material is described in detail above.

did.unittitle: Background research notes,
Monographs,
Announcements, fliers, miscellaneous,
Correspondence,
Published and unpublished articles, papers, and reviews,
Published and unpublished articles, papers, and reviews (continued),
Folk drama,
Field and research notes,
Field and research notes (continued),
Poems and personal writings (published ephemera),
Original tape reel (paper substrate; fragile),
Tape reel “master”,
Duplicated tape reels,
did.abstract: Duplicated tape reels of the materials in box 8, folders 18-19: a 10" restricted-use duplicate tape reel with background noise removed and a working 7" reel with names deleted; master cassette copies of the reels.
